Brush: The Movie

09 Jun 2011

My bath brush has a story. When I douse it in Dr. Bronner’s soap and buff myself silly, I think of this story.

I bought the brush at Mjolk in the Junction which specializes in Scandinavian design. It was made by Stockholm based  Iris Handverk using the same traditions–including the employment of visually impaired people to make the oak and horse hair brushes by hand–they’ve used since the 1800′s.

According to Mjolk’s owner, John Baker, who visited the factory, the brush factory is a pretty mystical space where everything happens in the dark as visually impaired workers work by touch. Brings a whole new meaning to the expression “handmade.”

This professionally produced video does an incredible job of showing the process required to make each hand-rendered brush. But it does more. It also mimics the experience of holding one of those gorgeous brushes in your hand.

 

The video’s sensuality turns something as mundane as a scrub brush into an artistic and mystical experience.

There’s no fetishizing of the workers’ visual impairment. It’s quietly suggested and respectfully rendered. It’s about the presence of well-worn hands, not the absence of sight. Which is what you’d expect from a company that is an offshoot of a Foundation for the Blind with a range of other social venture projects.

It’s what you’d expect from a company that makes brushes to suit every purpose you can imagine for kitchens, bathrooms, shoes, outdoors and cleaning. They also carry brushes available only by request.

As much as we advocate that everyone should get themselves a Flip and use it, there’s a valuable place for professionally made video. And a place for artistic vision. Perhaps most importantly, there needs to be time and space to consider how a video can enhance the experience and enrich the story.

Sure the video could be shorter. But so could War and Peace.

About us

Hypenotic is a marketing strategy, design & development firm that chooses to use its powers for good. We’re a certified founding member of B Corp in Canada, and if you don’t know what that is, it’s time you do. Since ’98, we’ve helped a lot of interesting people do important things. We create relevant communications and useful experiences. Find out more.
